Went to Tempest last week with friends and I really had no complaints. Sat outside which was perfect. Our waitress was excellent- definitely a pro. Smooth, friendly and knowledgeable. Our group had two appetizers - oysters Rockefeller and shrimp cocktail. I only tried the shrimp (not really an oyster fan) and though they were a bit pricey, they were very good. Came with some excellent sauces too. For dinner I had the shrimp po boy - but split it with our friend who got the lobster roll. Both were good but I preferred the shrimp a bit more. The breaking added some extra flavor. Only wish was that it was a bit more spicy or offered a Cajun type sauce to add on it wanted. It was my birthday so we tried a dessert - Key Lime Pie. It was beyond amazing. SO good, maybe the best I've ever had.

Interesting entrance. A Boat..Has a little I'm in Florida feel.....A little too dim lighting for me. Cool casual chill music.  Had the shrimp appetizer... was pretty good. Would've liked a little spicier for horseradish dip just picky me...  I ordered the Bucatani? Looks good What  good is good.

Romantic environment! They were about to close but we only came for late night appetizer before we went to hit up other places. I, of course ordered oysters! SO. GOOD.  The oysters were so fresh! I ordered the West Coast oysters because I heard they were more fresh and sweet. let's just say I could eat about ten of them!  I also tried my first oyster shot here. SMOOTH is all I have to say. Our waiter was awesome so the overall service was A+.

I find Tempest a bit over average, the food is good but unremarkable.... I suppose if you want a 'good' meal than this is the place, I had higher hopes... I know the dining room is loud (it has been for years), I expected the service to be just over average (and it was)...  yet I was really hoping for some 'wow' dishes. We had the oysters (which were great but don't really rely on cooking), the cooked clams however were like leather, everything else was.... fine.... With honorable mentions to the trout which was really tasty, and the deserts which were yummy. Maybe I eat too much spicy food and am being unfair, but the only spice I got here was salt and a lot of it on everything.

Loved this place!  Amazing oysters - which are rare in Madison!  I had the marlin crusted in pesto, and it was delicious!  Perfectly seasoned and not overcooked.  Desserts were also great, I think they change these up often.  My favorite thing about the place was the bar area!  Its such a light, inviting atmosphere that I could have stayed for hours.  A great change from the overly dark decor that was Magnus's signature.  Will definitely go back!

Wonderful. I've enjoyed many Madison restaurants and my overall (and first) experience at Tempest has outshined almost all of them. The food was amazing, the atmosphere was unique, and the service was fantastic. Everyone was perfectly polite, attentive, and timely. If you have the opportunity to visit during or outside of Restaurant Week, I highly recommend. Thanks for a great evening!

I had a great meal for my boyfriend's birthday at Tempest Oyster Bar.  We started with a selection of two of each of all the raw oysters and clams (we're addicts).  They had terrific oysters that were pretty expertly shucked (only got a couple of small shell pieces, and I've never been anywhere that didn't have that) -- a great variety of briny to creamy.  The clams were meh, but probably only because a raw clam seems a bit vulgar compared to the heavenly experience that is a raw oyster.  I also had the arugula salad, which was delicious, huge (the more arugula, the better!) and well-dressed -- not too lemony, with tasty bits of chevre throughout.  My entree, the carpetbagger steak, was out of this world.  Cooked perfectly (I asked for medium rare), in a "brown beer sauce" that I probably would have drunk out of a pint glass given the chance, it was stuffed with several --you guessed it -- OYSTERS!!  I nearly died eating it, it was so good.  I didn't even want to give a bite to my boyfriend and it was his birthday!  Definitely in the top five things I've ever eaten in my life.  Dessert was also delicious: I had a blackberry-peach crumble (not too sweet), and my boyfriend had a chocolate mini-bundt cake with a candle in it!  They also brought him shortbread cookies with whipped cream upon learning it was his birthday.  All were very tasty.  Great service.  Good wine list.  The decor was kind of weirdly sterile-nautical (try the bar section if you want to look at pretty things), but I don't concern myself much with that, especially when the food is to die for!

My wife and I tried oysters at the (gorgeous!) Tempest bar Sunday night. They were fresh, firm, plump...and clean! (I'm guessing the kitchen's pulling it together there). Love the decor and the smart and friendly staff. Will save up a little cash to go back for full dinners, but we will be there soon!  (Jimmy P. : I always had great service at Magnus and I'm pretty sure it was the "Scandinavian" menu that sunk that ship. Pun intended).

The best oysters in town!  Wide variety of both east and west coast oysters that are constantly changing from day to day. All are excellent!!  Other great things to eat include the smoke stack (a variety of fish mixed with egg and lettuce with topped with roe.  Capers, pickles, and pickled onion on the side!), fish chowder, mussels, conch fritters, and scallops.  Best special I ever had was softshell crab and morels, but it is hard to go wrong ordering whatever special they have. Wait service and ambiance are fantastic!  For the best deals, try happy hour from 4-7 PM weekdays (oysters are $2).

The owner painstakingly nailed hundreds of decorative metal spoons behind the bar & there's a giant wooden boat in the front room making most of the interior very cool (except for the clamshell in the wall).  The cocktails are simple, fresh, and delicious. I've had three of them and liked them all pretty well. Personal favorite is the Wheelhouse. Fairly solid beer selection too, including Schlitz.   Somehow I have an appetizer addiction, and Tempest helped fill my addiction. The seafood tower might not be worth the money - I'd just get oysters and clams a la cart. Last tower we got had some sketchy crab on the top which was a big turn off. The smoked fish platter is spot on -- you can't miss this. Also the scallop and clam apps are both very tasty.  Main courses have been nice also. Seems like the special is always pretty awesome. It's weird though - they seem to run out of things a little too often. Heads up: the lobster roll has lettuce inside of it, so make sure to get that removed. The sturgeon was okay - I think it's a personal thing. I also had the trout which was yummy.  Overall - I like this place. It's an innovative seafood restaurant in Madison with a refreshing interior.

Went for valentine's day, so it was obviously busy. Despite this, everything was cooked to perfection. Scallops were an excellent appetizer. Steak and whitefish (special for the day) were absolutely delicious.

I have to say I am a bit disappointed my first review was filtered by Yelp, but I went back last night to Tempest, and have more good things to say about them.  We ate in the bar instead of the restaurant this time, and the noise level was actually quite manageable.  I love lobster rolls (have lived on the East coast and have traveled to Boston and the New England area) and I was not disappointed with theirs.   I'm not sure if the recipe has changed since all of the bad reviews were written about it, but it was filled with perfectly cooked lobster meat.  Delicious.  It wasn't a traditional roll in the sense that it wasn't coated with mayonnaise and slopped on a hamburger bun (like street vendors in the New England area generally do) but it was very much like the high end lobster rolls I have gotten at places like Neptune Oyster Bar in Boston and the like.  The lobster is served on a butter toasted hoagie with a nice dollop of mayonnaise on the bun.  It was a perfect amount of fat, meat, and arugula.   The fries were also quite good that came with it, and the dipping sauce was nummer.    I have to admit that I wasn't a huge fan of the mussels.  Unfortunately, I am comparing it to Sardine's mussels, and none can ever compare.  The sauce was too salty and thick for my taste,  but the mussels were tender and debearded very well, so they were yummy.  My friend got the fish and corn chowder, and we had to send it back.  Sadly, it was quite bland and she pulled about 4 fishbones out before she gave up and signaled the bartender.  Ah well, it was only a side, so I can't complain too much.  All in all a very tasty dinner : )

In a land locked city such as Madison, there's reason to be skeptical of oysters.  But that said, the martinis served were iced to perfection, the oysters were delightful and offered a few varieties I'd not had before, loved the selection and the help from the staff.  Tried the scallops with a perfect sear and a fantastic bacon and apple bit sauce.  The decor is unique and feels hip and quaint at the same time.  Will be back to try more of the menu.

Hands down the best seafood restaurant in the city. the happy hour has  the best oyster specials in town and the cocktails are super tasty. check the schedule before you go and try to plan your trip on a live music night, the jazz band plays out of a gorgeous oyster shell stage, it's like being in a 1950's Hollywood movie.
Amazing food and unbelievable service. Alex and Eric were incredible. Great knowledge and recommendations on the menu. Thank you

The location was great. The service was on point. The menu looked very interesting and the wine list was pretty long and with a good variety.  Now the food. I shared the fruit de mer (basically fried seafood) and I hade the marlin. The fried seafood was pretty good, but the Marlin was really disappointing: the  Marline itself was fine, but the crust was way to heavy with mostly pistachios and the sauce was basically pure butter, the whole dish was in dire need of some acidity. The key lime pie was pretty good, but pretty expensive, and way too much cream! Luckily you can scrape that off, but no scraping off the butter from the marlin and even if you could scrape all of that and the pistachios off the fish, then the fish would be too thick for not having some acid to cut through it.  Having said that, there were plenty of dishes that looked interesting so I'm suspended between going back and trying something different or deciding it's not my place.

Such a lovely spot.  Great for going out with a small group or for a first date.  Intimate yet not packed in.  Can make a great drink.  Probably should like oysters and seafood, just in case you hadn't caught on.
Awesome decor and fantastic food.  Must try the scallops/shrimp, oyster rockefeller, mussles and salmon!

Heard of this new place, was excited to try it after the Bartell. Glad to see some empty tables in the first room. Waited by the host stand.... waited...waited... uh..w a i t ed. The many staff walking by never made eye contact. Ah - the guy chatting with his friends by the boat was the host I guess. Pretty young girl stands one second at the front desk - he pops right over. FAIL!  We walked out and had a fantastic experience and meal (as usual) next door at Osteria Popavero. Faith restored in food service.

Had a wonderful meal and left extremely full! We shared a HUGE raw tower and everything was absolutely delicious!! Such great oysters, lobster, crab and clams. We then shared the crab legs, and a lobster roll! The lobster roll was a bit too dressed for my liking-- I prefer just bread, butter, lobster and mayo, but this had arugula a bit too much bread. The fries were excellent and so were the crab legs! I'd definitely come back here again. Great service and attentive staff!!!

Fabulous!   Had some East Coast Oysters- Great!  The little brown vinegary sauce that is served with them is so good. We saved it to dip bread and stuff in! ;)  But don't wreck the oysters by adding the sauce- they are great alone. ' Also had the white fish cakes- yum!  I had the Marlin and tried the Halibut both excellent.    Everything was terrific.  Can't wait to go back.

Revisited with some new friends for dinner, we were not disappointed! My wife recommends the surf and turf burger, shrimp placed on top of a burger. I had the tuna and it was amazing. The shrimp and grits were also enjoyed. We also ordered a tower of oysters, shrimp and clams. The oysters were incredible.  -original review-  I had the occasion to visit tho establishment for a post holiday get together. I honestly was not expecting much as good seafood is very difficult to find in mid-America.  I was very surprised and pleased with their raw oysters. Very great and of high quality. Their fried oysters were incredible, I can only assume that they are using the fresh oysters for these as well. The fried oysters melted in my mouth. The other items were also very good and they seem to be using quality ingredients. While our group only had appetizers and drinks that evening, I would return for the oysters alone. I do intend to make a return visit sometime soon for dinner and shall hopefully have equally high praise then.

I loved their restaurant week menu! I had the caesar (which was great and good caesars are hard to come by) the shrimp and scallops and grits, which were awesome and the key lime pie.  I was pretty full by the time dessert came around but had a couple bites and it was good.  Our server was super knowledgeable and guided us through our oyster order and they were awesome!  Only reason for 4 stars and not 5 was that courses were very slow.  Had I not had an excellent dinner companion I would have been antsy.  I will definitely be back for happy hour soon.  I also loved the new decor much more than when it was Magnus.  Felt much brighter and lighter.

This is a great restaurant pulling off the improbable: the service of high quality no-hint-of-fishiness seafood in our land-locked city. It's tough to even get decent whitefish in Madison sometimes, so their impeccable service of chilled raw oysters and clams is deserving of high praise and patronage. Our assorted seafood platter was easily as fresh as oysters I had this past summer off the Chesapeake Bay. They were also correctly shucked----all of the liquid was left in the shell, no grit, no cracking.  Fish chowder soup was very good with a decidedly homemade flavor and lots of fish. Lobster rolls were generous portions for $15 and served with excellent fries. However, the lobster itself was served straight without any butter or mayo dressing on rolls covered in aioli. It was good, but they'd be smart to baste the lobster just a little. That said, again, no hint of fishiness at all, just fresh seafood.  The pear upside-down cake with homemade carmel and whipped cream may be the best dessert in Madison. Expertly executed and nicely warmed, it was so big that it fed 5 happy people.  They also have the best happy hour in Madison. All of their appetizers are significantly less expensive and their quality cocktails are only $5. Make a point to try whatever oysters they have at $1.50 each--a great deal. "Smoke stacks" are also on good happy hour special and are basically smoked salmon, whitefish, and a few other notes such as caviar stacked on top of each other with house-made pickled vegetables. Very good.  Do note that for dinner you'll spend a good $35-50 per person for appetizer, entree, and drink, and possibly more depending on what you order. I think you can go to the bar and just order a sandwich for $10-15, which is doable for undergrads.

Has become a classic for me, I go several times a year. I have never been disappointed with any dish.   Best oysters in the city, go during happy hour for better prices!  Decor is A++, as is service. They occasionally host amazing live music events, I strongly recommend going to one!  This is probably one of the best "fancy" date spots in Madison.

Stumbled upon as I was looking for a special dinner to celebrate my wife's birthday while we were in town for a conference. What a find! First, the room is really understated beautiful. The tones from dozens of candles against the barreled ceiling creates a warm and comfortable room. Service was top notch from a helpful and knowledgeable server who delivered the perfect amount of attention. We stared with oysters (of course) which were fantastic. Entrees were cooked perfectly and what a nice surprise to see Marlin on the menu. You must try the brussel sprouts!! Wish we had time to sit at bar and enjoy the place more....next time for sure.

Another solo dinner at the bar (on the road for business). The first thing that caught my attention was the entry way! Very nautical and tastefully decorated.  Had the seaweed slaw - which was really impressive. Definitely worth a go if you enjoy that sort of thing - you won't be disappointed. Followed that up with the Yellowfin tuna, rare. A lot going on with that dish - many different flavors that overshadowed the flavor of the fish, but not bad. Would have enjoyed the taste of the tuna a little more. Perhaps without the capers.   All in all a great experience - will return on my next trip to Madison.

I really enjoy the food at Tempest. The oysters and scallops are delicious. The drink menu is filled with tasty concoctions. I loved the complementary pickled vegetables served before our meal when we have eaten there. Service was generally in the not remarkable to pretty good range. However, I went for happy hour (which is really a great deal) and had a fairly negative experience there. Erin, our server, seemed not only not pleased to be there , but actively was openly irritated with us. We were patient and only made simple requests and did not complain about any of the food. She acted annoyed while we asked for an extra chair, needed split checks between three couples and ordered half a dozen more oysters. I was really disappointed in this level of establishment. I hope it improves.

I love the way the bar looks. If you haven't seen it, come see it. Hundreds of wine bottles stacked together underneath a smooth light wood bar. Subdued art deco and that shiny backbar. It's beautiful.  I sit in the middle of the bar and order a warm rum drink, a lobster bisque, and a carpetbagger. I've met a lot of the staff here, so they were fairly casual with me, but I wish they had steered me in a better direction with my orders.  The warm rum cocktail was totally fine with the horrible weather we've been having, but the bisque was pretty moderate. Bisques are heavily seasoned creamy crustacean soups, and while the bisque wasn't as hot or seasoned as I'd have liked (I want my bisque to be heavily salted and seasoned and gluttonous in general), the real offenders were the burnt capers and overdone bits of lobster. Now, I get that Wisconsin folks can be scared of seafood, but they're lobster! Figure out just how much to cook them before throwing them in hot soup and it's amazing.  A hip mixed couple sat down next to me at the bar. The man was a berret wearing Jewish gentlemen that kept company with a Japanese woman wearing legwarmers. We had a really good conversation.  The steak arrived mid conversation. I was kind of stunned with the presentation. Carpetbag steaks are oysters and steaks put together. Tldr carpetbag steaks are opulence for your mouth. What was on the plate was a 12 inch kabob through my 8oz tenderloin on top of a thin brown sauce. It didn't look rich which is a problem especially when it doesn't taste rich. I immediately tried ordering the scalloped potatoes (which I know are amazing), but I was told they were out. Hilariously when my chef buddy showed me the kitchen, there they were. I tried ordering anything *fast* so I could keep my meal going, but neither bartender knew what was quick. I ended up with hash browns.  Jazz starts. Dim yellow lights and shadows bounce around the contours of the giant sea shell at the end of the bar. Of course it's Wisconsin and they end their set with a birthday shout out.  My friends came and we sat and talked. Chef buddy from before is interested in food and we chatted a lot - especially about that carpetbagger. He agreed with me on p much all points. I probably could have complained my way to something else on the menu, but that wasn't really my goal. My other friend came and she ordered an Awniker and a smoke stack. Along with the Oyster Burger, those two are my go tos.  What's really funny is that while this review sounds pretty negative, I still like the place. It's really easy to discredit the ambiance, and conversation, and music. It's really easy to focus on my bad experience even though that Oyster Burger is maybe my favorite in Madison. To be honest, this review is just a long writeup about the small things that keep this place from being great.

There is a huge wooden boat when you walk in! Wicked. Also loved the huge sea shell in the bar area. Now just needs a mermaid to be sitting in it.  If you want to get a taste of what they are like. I would recommending going during Happy Hour.  $1.50 Oysters : $2.00 Shrimp Cocktail : $2.00 Fish Cake : $2.00 Rockefeller : $2.50 Scallop : $3.00 Smoke Stack  $5.00 Specialty Cocktails : $3.50 Rail Cocktails : $1.00 off all taps    The rockefeller was o.k. But the smoke stack stole the show with layers of whitefish salad, lox, trout, caviar, and horseradish cream.  Serves was slow. Was in a group of 15-20 and only gave us one server and it seemed that she also had tables for dinners in the dining room too.   Drinks were not strong and too sweet for me. The Bosun's Whistle was a fun twist with dill vodka. I got no heat from the jalapeno tequila in the Awniker.  Didn't get dinner but may return when/if craving seafood. Always wanted to try soft shelled crab and they do have that when in season.

Nice, very nice.  I did not expect to find a really good seafood restaurant in Madison, much less one that serves a good variety of oysters.  Needless to say, I was pleasantly surprised.  Nice atmosphere, there is an enormous wooden boat as soon as you walk in.  Dining outside was a bit dicier; there was enormous spider web and an enormous spider in its web on the window right next next to our table.  Anyway, small minus in retrospect as the food was excellent.  Oysters and clams were outstanding.  My dish was a play on the classic fish fry.  I never had Blue Gill before but I found it quite tasty and still delicate after a perfect cornmeal fry.  An excellent Key Lime pie topped off what was an excellent meal.  Highly recommend if you are in the area.
Highly recommend! Post before hunting food for this year's restaurant week! Miss oysters and juicy steak there!

Okay, I really hate spending this much money on one meal. But we do splurge once or twice a year for special occasions. We made reservations because we were going on Valentines Day. I thought it would be super crowded and loud but I was pleasantly surprised by the atmosphere. For food me and my husband split a Lobster Bisque and Mussles. They were both very good. My husband says its probably the best Lobster Bisque he's ever had. For our main course I ordered the Walnut Crusted Rainbow Trout and my husband ordered the Lamb with Scalloped Potatoes. Sometimes with a "crusted" fish the crust is very light and just a little hint of flavor. Well, this was definitely walnut! It was good, just more noticeable than what I was expecting. My husband really enjoyed his food and devoured it! The service was good, we never ran out of water (big pet peeve of mine!) and have no complaints whatsoever!
Killa food, great ambiance, and service rocked!! Everyone go there!! So good! Boat in entrance was surprising and you felt like you were on the water!

Came back second time for happy hour. And it was definitely worth it: only $2 for an oyster so we ordered 20 of them for 2 people and that was dinner for us. We also got the fish cake, scallop and fries on the side.   I would say this is the best place in Madison for oyster. They offer a wide variety of raw oysters. My fav is the west coasts ones. And those are a bit pricey so going during happy hour is a must. The Rockefeller is always good so if you are new to this restaurant, it is a must try.   Fish cake was perfectly cooked. Very crisp outside and moist inside. Personally for me, the fish flavor is just not as good as crab cake. But if you are judging the chef's cooking skills, it is 10/10 for this one.   Seared scallop with maple syrup was amazing. I love the maple sauce. The only down side of it is that they only serve 1 scallop per order.   Overall, Tempest made it to my regular list. I would recommend this restaurant and would definitely stop by here and there for a good oyster meal

5 stars just for the AMAZING interior.  Other things that are wonderful about this place:  - Tasty oysters  - great happy hour specials  - the mussels are different from any I've tried before, and in a good way- very light sauce. Oh and they are served with fire grilled bread :)  Definitely a place to visit in Madison (there are very few of those, so, you don't have an excuse not to)
Big fan of the scallops, and the French wine selection pairs well with any entree. Great place to take visiting family from out of town for a nice meal.

Best seafood outside of Maine. Just a delightful dining experience. We tried to go light because it was our third night out in a row in Madison celebrating my daughter's graduation from college. We couldn't stop eating so it didn't turn out to be too light. Smoked Stack was amazing. Bucatini was perfect. Oyster po boy topped all off but wait, there's more. We finished all off with key lime pie. Just a perfect evening. Service was great. Huge fans. We will be back.

Wow, just wow......... The food is awesome and lived up to their oyster bar name!  The service was a bit slow, and the bar area very loud, but for the quality of the meal it is worth the minor inconvenience of very busy server.  Definitely a repeat customer.

Full Disclosure: We're big fans of Henry Doan's other ventures. This one rates favorably with his other restaurants. I had the halibut cooked with capers and a savory sauce that was superb. My wife had the fish and chips. The fish was fabulous, but she's not a fan of shoestring potatoes (I like all potatoes and thought they were fine).  We ate at the bar and were given excellent service. it's an attractive bar with a good beer and cocktail menu. We didn't try any wines, but I noticed a good selection of by-the-glass wines.

I can't believe I have not been to the Tempest.  They've been open quite awhile but to tell the truth I had forgotten that the former business was no longer there.  You can tell I pay attention to downtown restaurant changes.  Well that is why I like to take advantage of Restaurant Week, which is what we did summer 2013.  We chose Tempest.  We ordered the Blue Marlin and the Salmon and both were delicious.  Hated to see the bottom of my plate.  The presentation was great very nice.  The bar has changed and they have a big boat in the lounge area.  We sat in the dining room however it looks like they have a decent sized outdoor seating area.  The deserts were scrumptious.  I ordered some raw oysters and really liked them.  We were told they came in fresh the same day and they sure tasted like they did.  The happy hour looks very tempting for oyster pricing and other fun specials.  The bar is fun and has been rearranged.  Give it a go if you like dining from the sea.  We did not participate in the fun drinks because it was a "school" night but looked like there were some fun choices.

This place is great. Great food and a great atmosphere. Come here at 4 for happy hour, oysters are only $1.50 a piece. I highly recommend this place. It's a great place to go for a romantic meal or just to eat oysters or hang out at the bar.

The food was pretty amazing if expensive.  Everyone at our table enjoyed the oysters but the whole deep fried sea bass stole the show.  Head and tail still on.  I was impressed.    The space is cool and feels retro yet new.    The problem I had was the bartenders and the lack of music.  On a Saturday night you'd think the bartenders would be in a good mood.  They weren't and their attitudes took something away from what should have been a great bar scene.    Overall the food is great but they need to make the place have more 'vibe'.  Its kind of stale even with the really cool decor (a boat inside!).

I've wanted to eat here for a few years now. The other day I was craving a po boy and my go to place had just closed. Thankfully I live on the same block as the Tempest. Perfect time to check the place out! Unfortunately it didn't live up to my expectations.  I've lived in a few different states and one of them had a fast food seafood place called Long John Silver. The breading on the po boy tasted JUST like the breading at the fast food restaurant. Kind of bland and way too greasy. Considering the price difference, I was very disappointed. On top of that the fries were bad. The only solace was in the aioli.  On the other hand, the crab soup was delicious and the key lime pie was absolutely amazing. I'm not sure if it's worth coming back for though, but they were almost good enough to makeup for the disappointing main course. In the future I'll likely stick with The Bayou when possible and maybe just grab a soup to go.

Tempest is a one of a kind seafood spot in Madison. The ambience is fun. It's classy, but not pretentious. It's warm and comfortable but kind of tacky in a wonderful way. The food will not disappoint. The scallop appetizer is among the best scallops I've ever had. My husband LOVES their swordfish (which isn't always on the menu, but is a frequent addition to the list of specials.) Everything I've eaten there from steak, to salmon, to tuna has been amazing. I also really enjoy the oyster shots.. they have a number of different alcoholic shots that they put an oyster in and serve it for $6. I like the one that has a tomato base, and the dill one is also quite delicious. I highly recommend Tempest for a nice date night out or for any special occasion.
This place is the BITCH. That being said, it's expensive and you get what you pay for. The marlin main and the smokestack starter are the tits

This whole place is different - Magnus is gone, and a delightful little oyster bar has taken its place. In the front, there is a boat. Not an image of a boat, but an actual boat. It's decor. It's kinda fun!  Magnus's old bar area has kept a little bit of its original majesty, and the main dining area is still separate. We were there late and they seated us in the bar zone at once. We ordered two dozen oysters. God I love oysters. It's what I'd probably request if I was going to be executed. No need for the little sauces but we ate them anyway. They were freaking great.  We also polished off a delicious chocolate dessert. Bonus points for having a sparkling chenin blanc on the wine list for $7 a glass. That was an easy choice! What's better than champagne and oysters? Delicious!

I had heard mixed reviews about Tempest, but I am happy to report that my dining experience did not disappoint. Our server was incredibly knowledgeable about the menu and was wonderfully attentive. He really did not miss a beat.  As far as the food, one of my dining companions had a sampler of the oysters and rated them at some of the best he has ever had. The one complaint I have is that they do not have a scallop or shrimp entree on the menu, which is rather disappointing. I ended up doubling the scallop appetizer for my meal, but found it was a little too sweet for my liking (prepared with apples, brandy, brown sugar, and bacon.) The three others I was with all ordered steaks (two bone-ins and one tenderloin) and all enjoyed their entrees.   We had been on Lake Monona all day, so the nautical-themed atmosphere was fitting. I did not think Tempest was especially loud. It was perhaps louder than L'Toile or Muramoto, but certainly quieter than Great Dane or Old Fashioned. Perhaps that is a big noise level range, but I was surprised to read that other reviewers rated Tempest at 'Very Loud.'  Overall, I thought Tempest was great. They succeeded in having a nautical-themed seafood restaurant NOT feel like a Red Lobster and the food and service was outstanding. I will definitely be back.

This place embodies everything I love about Madison.  We live in Chicago but regularly hit Madison for a relaxing weekend getaway that's honestly just as delicious as Chicago.  This trip fell during Lent, so we were in search of a spot for a Friday night fish fry.  After extensive research and the ultimate decision that we didn't want to drive outside the downtown area for a true supper club, Tempest won out.  When we got there we were worried it was way fancier than we wanted, but the service and atmosphere are actually much more casual than they first appear.  The fish fry wasn't on the menu, but I asked about it and they did indeed have it.  $17 for the fish (perch), fries, coleslaw and tartar sauce.  We decide to split that and add on the mussels and chowder for an appetizer.  Oh my gosh, fantastic.  The mussels were awesome, probably one of the best broth preparations I've tried.  The soup seemed pricey at $8, but was a HUGE bowl of rich, fish-packed soup.  And then the fried fish, ahhhh the fried fish.  Perfectly breaded, delicious tartar sauce, all around win.  And even with 3 drinks our bill was something like $75.  Honestly, what more can you ask for?

First time there and we immediately liked the atmosphere. Our server was very friendly and helpful with both the menu and our drinks. Speaking of which their mixed drinks were unique and well thought out. Oysters were great as well!

Do I miss the old Magnus (previous incarnation of this restaurant)? Most certainly. Both the Spanish and Norwegian versions. It was the best bar in Madison, hands down.  But I have to say that Tempest is among the most under-appreciated bar/restaurants in Madison.   Yes, you can go to Merchant, just up the block, but you can't get a seat and you can't hear the person sitting next to you. And the place is just an industrial space. Tempest is genuine plaster walled vintage. And that boat in the front lobby is a solid wood beauty.  Drinks are expertly made, the seafood is fresh, and if you get the #2 tower between 2 couples. you have the equivalent of 4-5 appetizers. Plus the clam shell is beautiful, and if you close your eyes, you are back at Magnus.   Again, one of the most under appreciated bars in Madison.

Right off the bat: this review is coming from someone who's not a big seafood guy. That being said, I was pleasantly surprised here. Drinks are not bad and their cocktail menu is decently inspired. I ordered the Marlin which was actually quite good. Decor of the place is a bit confused: I really want to like the big boat when you come in and sea-inspired pieces, but it just doesn't come off quite right. Everything feels like individual pieces decorating a white blank room, almost like a eating in the middle of an underfilled art gallery. Overall though, we enjoyed ourselves.

These folks have Saturday & Sunday Brunch! This should be highlighted in Google Searches. I'm mad that I never considered it or remembered such.  The brunch menu is egg heavy/reliant upon eggs but WAFFLES are offered.   The Happy Hour includes Rockefeller Oysters so I'm going in today to compare them to (a) their sister restaurant, Tornado Room; (b) Rare, the new steakhouse on the Capitol and (c) Cap Chophouse.   Update forthcoming.

Came here for Friday night fish fry based on a recommendation. They only had bluegill and not the perch today, plus cod as always. The bluegill was well seasoned and fried, but I was honestly very disappointed by how little fish there was. 6 small pieces for $16. The $18 cod that a dining companion got was 2 huge pieces that he said was the best batter he's had. We did get solid sourdough bread to start. I would go elsewhere for fish fry unless you don't eat much - I like having a lot of delicious fish.
Really really good. The food was very good, great selections. The service was top notch. The decor and ambiance were perfect. We will most def go back!

The food was good at first. Happy hour is a great deal! I had high hopes for this place when I arrived with my friend. We got here a half hour before our party of six and so headed to the bar for cocktails. The high sea is a good drink. Good atmosphere. Those are the only positives I have about this place.   What made this place a two and borderline one star was the service. It was INCREDIBLY slow! Also-happy hour doesn't apply to the seated area-only the bar. I was shocked. It took an hour to get out our food... We asked for our check as soon as the food came because we were running late to our nine o clock trivia. (We sat at our table at 6:45 and ordered at 7:15/20). We got our food at 8:41-I checked the time.   Absolutely unacceptable service here. Would not recommend it. Sardine is a much better place to get food and better service by far.   And the guy mixed up our receipts.   Horrible service.

We went for their oyster happy hour.  It was early and pretty empty, but it's a great space.   We sat at the bar--the bartender was low-key and professional and made some fantastic martinis.  The oysters were well-priced and delicious.  Just one tiny little request-- it would be nice if they wrapped the lemons in cheesecloth like they do at Graze so that seeds wouldn't pop onto the oyster.  That's a really tiny issue, though.  We were very impressed.

I brought my girlfriend here for an early Valentine's Dinner on a Sunday. The dining room is very open but cozy all at once; it wasn't very busy, but there was enough of a crowd to provide a nice ambiance. I find it really awkward to be the only two in a dining room so some background noise is always nice. Service was outstanding. Our waiter was friendly and you could tell he was well versed in the art of fine dining.  Their beer and wine list had something for everyone. I ordered beer, she ordered wine. They were of course very good... it's hard to find a bad drink in downtown Madison. I've also heard that their cocktail menu is creative and delicious though I did not order one.  (Quick note: Everything here revolves around the sea. From the name and decor to the design of each dish. If you like seafood this is probably THE place to eat in Madison.)   We shared a scallop plate as our appetizer. Two nice sized scallops, pan-fried with lardons and little diced apples. The brown sugar and brandy combo brought everything together. Tender and savory with the perfect sweetness to it. My favorite dish of the night.  I then had a crab bisque. Quality stuff. The seafood here is just so good. I dipped a little bit of their homemade bread in it, and I don't regret the decision.  For the main course she had the rainbow trout and I had the bucatini. Her plate was simple. Vegetables and a whole breaded trout. Simple, but the breading complemented the fish so well. Gave it a small crunch to each bite of light, airy fish. My plate had mussels and a scallop, and one giant shrimp all served with thick spaghetti noodles. I usually avoid spaghetti, but tasted as great as all the rest.  Finally, for dessert we had an upside down pear cake (served warm) with homemade whipped cream. Again it was, like every other part of the evening, perfect. Especially with a cup of coffee.   Final thought: Eat here! You will not regret it.

Food is more than "just ok". We order two starters and two main dishes - all good to very good.  Service is ok ( could and should be close to very good, but it's not) Dessert....only 4 option without anything special or creative. We skipped.

Food was very good but it was quite overpriced. Over $140 after tip for two with only a 3 mixed drinks. The waiters seemed a little bored with their job and the place was very empty on a weekday night. I would recommend going on a weekend night for a better atmosphere.
We ate there last night. We had to wait forever to get our main course for below average food.

If you like Seafood you have to add Tempest to your list.  I had an exceptional experience trying Tempest for the first time.  The Oysters were absolutely delicious.  They offer a variety of Oysters From both the East and West Coast.  They also have a selection of clams, mussels, and crab.  Make sure to get one of the towers of hand picked oysters, clams, mussels, and crab by the chef.  You will not be disappointed.  I had the tuna for my main course and it was truly exceptional.  I will definitely be back.

There is nothing, and I mean NOTHING bad about this place. I love it. From the vibe, to the restaurant decor, to the food, everything was great.  I loved the amount of detail and creativity they put into the restaurant. When you walk in there is this large wooden boat, which I've never seen in a restaurant!  I came here for a wedding rehearsal dinner, which was a pretty decent size party, and the experience was great. There was a spread of oysters, cheeses, shrimp, mussels, fruit, calamari, salad, chicken, rice, and crackers. The starters were so good, there was nothing bad. I couldn't stop eating. The servers made sure we had drinks the entire night, and had something on our plate. After the starters, the servers came around with burgers, blue gill sandwich, and shrimp skewers!  After the food, they then brought out key lime pie and some kind of dark chocolate pecan pie that was amazing.  I truly enjoyed this place and highly recommend it!!

Service: Subpar. Barely could get our waiters attention, yes I understand when you are busy it is hard to pay attention to ALL of your customers, but waiting for a drink for 25 minutes is a bit of a stretch. Service was one of the main downfalls of the visit.  Atmosphere: Ambiance of the place is great, lively, separated for intimacy, but a bit dirty. The window sills hadn't been cleaned in a while and there were dead bugs on it (which was right next to our table where our food was placed). The whole place looked like it needed a little TLC. I think a remodel in the near future would help, so all the table are a bit larger, even as a party of 2 our table was quite crammed. Maybe some colors on the walls?  Food: Brilliant. Not a single thing wrong with the meal, I had the marlin and it was superb. My boyfriend had a steak with the snow crab. Best crab either of us has tasted in the Midwest. They oysters were fresh and our waiter did a great job answering questions about what was fresh and what we would experience in difference for farmed vs. wild oysters.  We will be stopping by at least once more to see if the service and cleanliness will be improved on. Looking forward to updating my review after our next experience.

So asking me to rate an Oyster place is like asking Tiger Woods to rate a golf course. I grew up eating seafood nearly every day and have eaten seafood in just about every state in the country and several other countries.   For where this restaurant is located the Oysters are of good quality and are fresh. The Blue Points were my favorite. There was no shell in the oyster, they all tasted great and they were detached from the shell so they slide out easily. I admit the cost was a little more than I normally pay but what do you expect a few thousand miles from the ocean. If I wanted a deal I would be here at happy hour.

My dining companion and I went to Oyster for the Happy Hour and we were not disappointed! We spent way more than we had anticipated but I have no regrets. The oysters were delicious. We also ordered the lobster po boy and it was very good! Some of the tastiest food I've had in Madison.

Wow. Straight up some of the best, most unique cocktails I have ever had anywhere! So glad we stopped in for some before-dinner cocktails last weekend; we had an absolutely great experience.   Walked in right after they opened at 5:30 and told the first server we saw that we'd just be drinking. He led us into the bar and when we told him that we'd be joined by another couple, he suggested we sit in the seashell. You have to see it to appreciate it but basically one end of the bar area has been formed to resemble the inside of a shell-complete with a round 'pearl' light right in front of it. So unique and somehow not as tacky as you'd think. I doubt I would even have noticed it had the server not pointed it out.   Very cool bar area and dining area as well. Love the old boat sitting in the middle of the front room. It takes up a lot of space but really adds a lot to the atmosphere.   The cocktail menu will have you saying 'oooo that sounds good' with every entry. It was very hard to choose so I just started at the top. The jalapeño tequila drink first on the list was simply outstanding. The server was wonderful and made great suggestions. Never steered us wrong. All cocktails that everyone tried were excellent. Even the sake cilantro one was great and I wasn't so sure about it since sake's not normally my thing. Yum!   Someday I'll have to come and try the food!

Hoorayy for my first yelp event ever! And a huge thanks to Tempest for hosting us. (:   My two cents:   Cocktails - sound good on paper, but I wasn't particularly impressed by my Batida or Tokyo Schooner. The bartenders pour with a heavy hand, so I still ended the night on quite a high note...but I guess I like my drinks tasting a little more like the mixers and a little less like the alcohol.   Scallop - 5 stars. Self-proclaimed pescatarian? Not anymore! I just ate all the bacon on top...and I don't feel guilty at all!  Oysters - Fresh, fishy, perfect. Gone way too quickly.    Bar service is slow, but prices are reasonable during happy hour. I do think I will be back eventually to try their full menu!

Excellent. I am getting the feeling all the Madisonites flee to the 'burbs after work and leave all these wonderful restaurants empty. Tempest is another marvelous treasure in the pool of Madison gastronomic pleasures. I made sure to get all my tastings in before happy hour expired. I started with one of every oyster and a couple of clams. It is so much fun eating your way around the sample platter of little mollusks. They were all delicious and quickly slurped up with their brine. I also double ordered cocktails for the discount and the Awniker had a fantastic back of the throat burn from the jalapeno. I was craving a Mai Tai and the Cabin Boy was a great sub; a citrus fruity version of a Mai Tai. I followed with the conch fritters; good tasty with a hint of some Indian spice but if you plan to eat a belly full, they could be skipped. Next I tried to be a little healthy and had every intention of stopping sooner but I ordered the asparagus and, thankfully, abbreviated happy hour smoke stack with some saltines. The Stack was perfect blend of smoked seafood and egg... I didn't understand the pickled stuff and how that was supposed to play into the dish. By now, I really should have just said, "Check, please." but instead I asked about the Oyster Po'boy and then the the Surf and Turf with oyster sandwich; crap. I wasn't exactly full but I knew if it wasn't quick my tummy would finally get the signal to my brain to stop eating. Unfortunately, the burger took a little longer and I got the DING I'm done and the burger arrives WITH fries. I picked up the warm soft to the touch bun and looked for the morsels of fried oysters tucked under the bun. Lovely!!! It was delicious; I did all I good to shove it in my mouth to pack everything tighter into my belly. Smartly, I asked for the check and the fries to go and I am now enjoying the perfectly fried fries, writing this review, and watching Dark Knight. Through all of this Avery was a delight the whole time for the 2 hours that I sat and engorged myself. I was never wanting or waiting, except for the burger, and I am just glad she did not offer "And finally, monsieur, a wafer-thin mint." I will definitely be coming back here before I leave to enjoy the happy hour a little more.

Tempest is so cool, from the entrance to the bar to the dining room, there are no bad spots to sit back and enjoy a bite to eat or a drink.   When my wife and I lived in Madison we used to enjoy eating in the bar's lounge area and hanging out in the clam shell. Yup, the clam shell!   If the bar isn't your thing, never fear, the dining area is beautiful.   Service is friendly and prompt.  Cocktails are delicious.  Food is on point.

Romantic, yet ok with friends as well, unusual, great food...if you want to go to Red Lobster, please do. However, if you want an experience, a conversation over great food, then this is the place. And the best snackie thingies, hands down, in the square area after work. Good beers on tap.

Wow... EXCELLENT seafood. I don't like oysters so I can't speak for the oysters but I did have several other types of seafood that were all amazing. The mussel appetizer comes with a lot of mussels that are so delicious you will want to gobble them up in 2 minutes. For the main I ordered the shrimp, scallops, and grits. Don't expect grits- it's more like a sauce/paste, but the shrimp is tasty and the scallops melt in your melt like butter! It also includes a large piece of pork that is possibly one of the tastiest pieces of pork I've ever had. I would come here and order the same thing again if I revisit the area. It looks spooky from outside but it's a nice ambiance inside.

You can serve me terrible food. You can mix me a crappy cocktail.  Your ambiance can fall flat.  You can even charge me more than I want to pay.  But take note Tempest (and really any other business in Madison and beyond) you can't be complacent. I mean you can, but I will not patronize your business nor will I recommend it.   When you turn the lights on, polish flatware and open your doors you are entering into an agreement with those that are coming to spend money that you want their business. But after 4 visits and an event that I unfortunately brought 28 people out for, you have done nothing to make me think you a. want my business, b. care to make money. So I have to ask... why show up to work?   Tonight was the last straw. My friend and I were sitting at the bar for ten minutes before someone came over not to ask us what we wanted to drink or to show us menus, but to stand there. To stand there and look at us blankly until we asked if happy hour was still going on. He said yes and lobbed the conversation back our way, didn't go over the happy hour specials of which there are many. I felt terrible for suggesting we grab light bites and drinks to this friend who had never been to Tempest.   *flash forward*  I'm not eating sugar right now and the brown sugar sauce that tops their scallops is entirely too sweet, so I asked for seared scallops with the bacon lardons that typically top the dish but not the sauce. I explained if the kitchen wasn't interested in accommodating my request and leaving the sauce out, I'd find something else. Surprise, the scallops came out with the cloyingly sweet sauce and this is how the next few moments went:  BARTENDER: Yeah, I said just the scallops and lardons, so maybe they can't separate the lardons from the sauce?  COREY: Ok, well I don't eat sugar, so I can't really eat these, there's no way to get just seared scallops, no sauce? BARTENDER: I mean, that's what I asked for, so I guess they can't do it. Did you want these?  (I'm sort of fuming at this point) COREY: No, I mean I can't do the sugar so.... BARTENDER: They'd be on the house.  GO TO THE KITCHEN AND SAY THESE CAME UP WRONG, CAN YOU SIMPLY SEAR SCALLOPS AND PUT BACON ON THEM? What's the challenge here?   *flash forward some more*  Drinks went empty, food was eaten, and it took forever to catch someone's eye to get refills or order more. Why? Because it was more important for a gaggle of servers to talk with the bartenders about what a proper wine pour looks like. I counted 5 at one point staring at the same glass of white wine, then repeating this behavior 15 and 25 minutes later. So detail oriented.  Last up, the gent that cases the joint, a manager I assume, does laps around the restaurant every time I've been there, but never asks how we're doing. And that's really the crux of my issue. I know full well a business can't be 100% "on" 100% of the time, we all have bad days. But when leadership at the top has no vested interest in how people spending hard earned money feel about their establishment, that trickles down, and I want no part of it.   There are plenty of restaurants in town that serve seafood by people who are interested in striking up conversation, making menu recommendations and righting wrongs that may occur when things go awry in the kitchen. I'll go to those places, a giant wooden boat and tea lights don't do it for me.

Love this place for Happy Hour Monday through Fridays from 4-7! Really nice place inside, although the lighting is a little dark. I've never actually come here outside of Happy Hour (because prices, yikes) but $2 oysters and shrimp cocktails I could never say no to. The oysters are delightfully fresh and come out on a beautiful tower. They always feature different east coast and west coast oysters to choose from and the waiters are always very helpful in deciding what to order (or if you're me, you just close your eyes and point). Simply awesome, fat, juicy shrimp cocktail that come with cocktail sauce and horseradish in a small martini glass.   Appetizers like the calamari are always a good pairing as well. Cocktails at Tempest are also phenomenal and surprisingly strong so beware! Great place to come with friends after a long week to kick back, try some new oysters, and get a little tips.
Bright and fun on the inside. Food was good. Service was friendly and on the spot.

We tried this place on a whim in the spring, it was amazing! I would give it 4.5 stars.  The oysters were delicious, we split the special which was prime rib and yorkshire pudding, and we still talk about the meal 6 months later. It is pricey, but worth the one or twice a year splurge.

Intimate and low-lit space evocative of a hidden European cafe that only the locals know about. Great for a date night or small gathering of friends... noise can carry easily but otherwise a lovely place to spend a night out.

As a 19 y.o., I can't speak to any of the booze options at this place, but I certainly can speak to everything else. Took my significant other here for her birthday, and we were both very pleased. Smoked sampler was out of this world. She is a very picky eater, and she raved about their salmon dish. I tried the rainbow trout, which was presented in an interesting fashion (head, skin, and tail included), but tasted fantastic. On that note, I would say I have a bone to pick, literally, as I found several in my fish. Our service was excellent and very quick, and to top things off, when our waitress learned it was my girlfriend's birthday, dessert was on the house! It was a wonderful experience. One of my favorite seafood places I've ever been to, and I LOVE my seafood.  I understand what many said about poor lighting, but I would put my two cents in to say, it's not unusually dark... It was certainly dim, but for a dining room with not a lot of privacy and plenty of candles, I thought it was quite enjoyable...   Dined 10/09/15

Visited several times for dinner service and haven't been let down. A hidden gem not far from the square, whether you're looking for oysters, fresh seafood or even a solid steak, Tempest's menu has something for everyone. Looking at their late night and happy hour menus, I think I'll try visiting earlier and later in the day soon. Many of the great items I love offered at lower prices. Solid cocktails as well.

I agree with Ariel W. all the way around. Great happy hour specials, especially in Madison where I have yet to find an awesome happy hour.  The smoke stack was amazing! Especially for $3, totally worth it. Order two! The oysters were good, many varieties available.   Service was extremely slow...perhaps they expected fewer patrons on a Tuesday night, but we sat with empty glasses for at least 20 minutes, waiting to order a second drink and food (first drink was ordered from the bar).   Nevertheless, I'll give the Tempest a second chance. If they expand their happy hour food offerings and hire a few more servers, this could be a regular go-to happy hour spot.

I've been to Tempest twice now and enjoyed both experiences.  The service was welcoming and attentive, we were seated immediately and checked on just the right amount during our meals.  The she crab soup was delicious, with chunks of real crab in light tomato cream base that doesn't overpower the flavor of the crab.  The shrimp and scallops in the shrimp, scallop, and pork belly dish were perfection.  The pork belly, while good, was too much - I'd have preferred a smaller piece with more shrimp or scallops.  The decor is simple, but fits the nautical theme well without being campy.  Oysters and cocktails are a nice addition to a good meal.  Overall I highly recommend Tempest.

We visited tempest for my birthday last weekend and my wife and I were very excited to experience a special night (away from our little ones as well). I ordered their special, a Lobster Pot which was billed as a fresh water lobster boiled on a bed of shrimp, mussels, andouille sausage and veggies.  When it came, the lobster was tougher than normal and over cooked.  Below the lobster was a couple pieces of andouille and veggies, oh yeah...  One shrimp.  When I brought the discrepancy to the servers attention, she dropped a plate with four cold mussels and A shrimp on our table.  As we were settling our check, we brought it to a employees attention.  After conferring with someone, they took our drinks off which came to $20.  My wife shared her King Crab Kegs which were quite good.  Bummer my birthday dinner was ruined.

We went on a Friday, there were two tables outside and it was the first beautiful day in Madison after a long time so we wanted to sit outside. One table was taken by a couple, but we got seated at the other right away. I wouldn't judge a place harshly on a Friday during happy hour but this was just that bad. After 5 minutes of sitting, a person came to give us water - - she said our waitress would be out soon. Ten minutes pass, someone else comes out, quickly sets plates on our table and walks away before we can ask where our waitress was. Meanwhile, the couple next to us has their drinks and soon after gets their appetizers. They even said "wow this is the fastest we ever got them". Their waitress had her back to us the entire time and we felt extremely uncomfortable to run after her. By this time we waited for about 15-20 minutes and happy hour was almost over. We said if we had to sit there for another 5 minutes without anyone coming out we would leave... Surprise, no one shows up. We get up and walk away down the street. We turn back around to look at our seats, and SOMEONE WAS CLEANING OFF OUR TABLE. So someone was able to quickly clean the table, but not even take our order? Ridiculous.

I've been back to Tempest twice since my first review and I'm bumping them to a 5. Biggest reason: consistency. Every experience at Tempest has been thoroughly enjoyable with a warm and inviting ambiance, excellent staff, amazingly fresh and delicious seafood, and fun had by all! My first review is more comprehensive but Tempest has earned the fifth star in my book!

While I have been here many times for dinner and loved it, this review is in reference to a party I held at Tempest. Chip, the manager was incredibly helpful and responsive. He helped me figure out the best food to serve for my guests, where to set up the tables, food and drink and every detail for the party - all via email, my preferred method of communication. He was prompt in responding and happy to help with suggestions. When the night of the party arrived, his staff had prepared a beautiful space with many bar tables and chairs, a convenient area to place the food and easy access to the bar. We also had a server dedicated just to our party who was very personable, kind and helpful. They, and the many bartenders who served us, made the night seamless and fun. The food was wonderful and refreshed without anyone having to ask.
First time here. Service was awesome and so was the food. The bartender and manager,Chip, were amazing! Took great care of us.  Thanks Tempest! Will be back!!

Awesome! It's pricey but for a special occasion, it's perfect! Came here twice with my boyfriend for our anniversary and both times I've loved it. It was about $80 worth of food for two people but you will not be disappointed. The food was DELICIOUS! If you like sea food and want to go out somewhere fancy, this is the place for you!

I stopped here for a drink and a bite at the bar before an event I was going to elsewhere.  I was happy to see a Happy Hour.  I had a nice German Pilsner for 4 dollars (a buck off) in a tall glass.  I ordered four oysters and the conch fritters.  Tempest does a good job bringing in good oysters.  The Naked Cowboys were large and tasty.  I had heard good things about them and they didn't disappoint!  The Conch Fritters were good but fried maybe a little too long.  They were a little on the darker side of golden.  The sauce served with them saved the day.  It was so good I was thinking of other things I would like to add the sauce too.    The bartenders on duty were nice and attentive.  I was brought a water just prior to my meal being served without even being asked.  I was checked on and acknowledged the duration of my visit.  I would like to try Happy Hour again...maybe a dinner too.

fresh & delicious clams in the Midwest? I am in!! Very good food.... a bit pricey but not completely out of control...... we had a fabulous meal and will be back and will hope that our server is better next time!

Nice place. Deceiving from outside but it's very decent inside. Simple decor but well appointed. Great quality food and exceptional service. We had the mussels which is pretty big fir an appetizer. There was a sword fish special which was very tasty.  The wine list is extensive and they have a wide range of prices. This was a nice surprise to have a place with such a nice wine list in Madison.  The desserts were awful!  We got this brownie crunch bar thing that you can easily buy at a "Gas Station" counter. Yes, it was that bad and goofy. The pouched pear tart was just as bad. They really need to hire a pastry chef or simply sell cookies or only cheese for dessert.

We had a group of 4 and went to for dinner around 8. We only had to wait 10 minutes, about the time to grab some drinks. I had the windjammer specialty cocktail, which was very good. Service was great, would definitely come back for dinner.   Appetizers: Shrimp Cocktail Entree, Smoke Stack, and Fruits de Mer  The smoke stack had a combination of different seafood in an elegant tasty package. Highly recommended.   Entrees:  Shrimp Po' Boy - standard Po' boy but I will note that the breading was great on the shrimp. Often times you see the breading coming off mid-way through the sandwich - not here.   Blue Marlin - probably the best dish. Uniquely prepared and fantastic taste.   Special of the day:  Friday Perch Fish Fry - classic fish fry, well done.  Duck Breast - Very rich and full of flavor. Tasty but a little too much fat left over.

We sat outside and enjoyed great service as well as good food. The shrimp poboy was delicious and the tower was outstanding. We kept adding people to our group-- my kids arrived in shifts, and our server was quick to accommodate them and bring them food. Eating here was a spur of the moment decision but we were delighted that we did!

I have always heard of how wonderful this place was, and today I finally got a chance to experience it myself! I came during the happy hours. First of all, the restaurant is very beautiful. The shells made me feel like I was a mermaid eating under the sea lol  I tried the happy hour menu:  1) Oysters-I added the lemon juice and vinegar (with garlic?) to all. Naked Cowboys-They are a must try! They were so fresh, sweet and crispy at the same time. They almost let me scream when I ate them! Wianno-also a sweet and crispy one, but not as outstanding as the naked cowboys  Shigoku-a west coast oyster recommended by the staff. Didn't like this one that much. It's more salty. But what is really interesting about these oysters is that you could really taste and discover how different they are from place to place!  2) Smoke Stack- basically fish salad. The top layer was smoked salmon and the bottom was a mix of greens, some white fish and eggs. You might get sick of the taste after a few bites, but I guess that's what the onions and pickles are there for. The sour cleansed out the taste buds really well. And as suggested by the staff, do not forget to save some bread to go with the fish! This was the most impressive and special item I had for today!  3) Scallop Didn't like this too much. But I guess if people have a sweet tooth, this might be the one. It comes with a sweet sauce, maybe caramel, with apples and pork in it. The scallop was a little overlooked for me, but it was very flavorful within.  Had a good time here! Don't forget to pair your meal with a nice wine!

Nice environment, with good service and good food. It's a great place for a nice date (think Valentine's Day). My one complaint would be with their cocktail selection, which left me wanting... But the fish and Brussels sprouts were excellent!
Great food. Four of us had a tower, chowder, cakes, slaw, fresh lobster, mussels, real fish & chips. Would be 5 star but service was pokey.

Fireworks in my mouth!! Holy moly I've never had anything so delish! Every bite of every plate was spectacular!!!   The fish corn chowder was absolutely amazing. I highly highly recommend you check this place out when you're in Madison. It did not disappoint.   Exceeding every expectation from other friends who recommended we try it!

I love everything about Tempest.  It's cozy, they have great food, and it might be the best happy hour in Madison. Did I mention the happy hour? It goes til 7 (the latest of the happy hours on the square) and features a lot of their items from the dinner menu at half-price.   My favorite favorite happy hour item is the Smoke Stack. It's a combo of fresh seafood including smoked salmon, caviar, trout, and whitefish. The conch fritters are also quite fabulous. We ordered the shrimp cocktail and the fish cakes; they were decent, but not our favorites.  Their drinks are decent too, although not quite the steal as the happy hour food. They have house wine for $6 and last time I was there, it was a NZ sauv blanc. Score!  The space is cozy with a different feel in each area. The dining room is intimate and dim. The front room is bright and friendly, while the bar is lively. I look forward to going to Tempest just to try out each room.  When every other happy hour on the square ends at 6, head here!

I've only experienced the Tempest bar. With limited time in Madison, I had a list of places friends suggested I go, and I tried to cram them all in my short trip. What I can say is that every dish I saw looked delicious (I did sneak some tastes), and I'd happily return to eat a proper meal. As a business traveler that frequents solo dining experiences, I can say that the team at Tempest was awesome. All were incredibly friendly and quite amusing. The bar, led by Nick that night, was entertaining (pony up at the bar and you'll be happy). He's a great mixologist, taught me how to peel a lemon as a garnish, and we all tried some new concoctions.  I highly recommend stopping in. My girlfriend gave a great recommendation and it's worth passing on.

3.5 stars. Service had a slow start but ended up being pretty good although we were bummed to hear the specials being told at the next table - our server was so delayed in the beginning that she didn't tell us the specials. The shrimp cocktail was AMAZING minus one poop shoot not being removed. That sauce though .. yum! Don't get the scallops. They are so laden with a sugar reduction sauce that all you taste is sweet. For $15, you want to make sure you taste those beautiful sea scallops you're paying for. The bread was disappointing. Only a very tiny bit of soft bread vs the amount of hard scrape the roof of your mouth crust. Loved the raspberry point and Irish point oysters. Caesar salad was ok.  My boyfriend and I split the 8 oz tenderloin and scalloped potatoes for $34. Those potatoes were amazing! Delicious. Yum. The steak .... well hmm. Although it was tender, it wasn't a filet. Or at least didn't resemble one at all. It tasted like pot roast. Not that pot roast isn't good, but $34 for a steak, you want that baby to be like a delicious buttery filet. I would not recommend the steak at all.  We will return but it will be for the oysters and shrimp cocktail only and perhaps we will sit at the bar so service is improved.

Cute place. Food was yummy. One strange thing... They delivered steak and potatoes first and then 5 minutes later, out came our Brussels sprouts.  Service could have been better and woman hostess could have been nicer.

Tried Tempest for the first time on a Friday night at 6:30. Trying to find parking was a hassle. But once we got there our table was waiting for us.  Dining room was not super busy, but getting our food was slow, and rarely saw our server.  Sharing the fried seafood appetizer was good and plentiful, but slightly over cooked. After waiting an hour for our entrees we inquired of the server.  She said they were just being plated....but 10 minutes later and still no food, we tracked down the manager. He went to personally check on our meals, and said 5 more minutes.... Sorry your kitchen was SO SLOW we walked out. Not sure why it took FOREVER for 1 salmon and 2 soft shell crab.... we would have liked to actually EAT them....
The food was good but it took almost 45 mins to bring the food to us. The environment was nice and quiet.

I paid Tempest a visit during Restaurant Week at the end of July and was kicking myself afterwards for not having stopped in sooner because Tempest is fantastic. The atmosphere, service, and quality of the food is on point.   We dug into a 3 course meal for an incredibly fair price of $35, and what's more is the portion sizes didn't appear to be scaled down in the least. During restaurant week, you'd expect restaurants to provide you with the same food items, at a cheaper price only because the amount of food is substantially less. This was not the case at Tempest. After a delicious appetizer, entree, and dessert, we left here stuffed.  While the namesake oysters were not on the restaurant week menu, we knew that was something we had to experience. We simply ordered one west coast and one east coast oyster and both were fresh and well worth the extra expense.  Then for my first course I chose the She Crab Soup with King Crab & flying fish roe. I am typically not a soup person, which makes this selection curious, but I had heard great things and having now tasted it, I am glad I did. The soup was very creamy and had a unique yet delicious flavor to boot.  The second course was the Blue Marlin, broiled with hazelnut pesto lime aioli & fried leeks. I loved this fish. It was a large filet and I polished off every last bite. The outer crust was perfection and the taste of the pesto and salty crunch from the leeks were great with this particular fish.  For dessert I chose the Chocolate Caramel Walnut Tart and boy was this a large slice of decadence. From the thick layer of hardened chocolate to the gooey caramel interior and interspersed walnuts, my mouth salivated with anticipation between bites. I don't recall putting my fork down until I had near cleaned my plate of this very rich, very indulgent dessert.   I took advantage of a few spots during this latest restaurant week, but Tempest has stuck out in my mind as one of the best.

I took my boyfriend here for his birthday, and it was definitely worth it. We were able to get some happy hour specials, which are great (they go from 4  to 7 pm on week days). First off, the cocktails are spectacular. Second, we are novices to oysters and I ate all west coat oysters which I would recommend to newbies; they're a little more delicate and softer in flavor. We also had their fish cakes which were super, super good. If you like crab cakes you will love these as well. I had a lobster roll and my boyfriend had a scallop and pork belly entree, which were both very good and tasty, but honestly I'd probably come back just to do appetizers, oysters, and drinks. Also, very dim atmosphere, which I liked.

We came to this place to have a birthday dinner.  We had a great cocktail shrimp and fruits de mer as our appetizers. The latter came in a huge portion but so good.  Tho it's cocktail, the waiter confirmed no alcohol involved. I guess the name is coming from the appearance. Maybe.  Out tips: If you wanna save some money but still want to have some delicacy, the appetizer is more than enough.  Ps. We brought our main dishes home as we were still full from the appetizer.

I just got chance to write this review for my experience during RW 18. The $35 for three courses is a great deal as for the normal menu, most entree itself price is 25+. For this 35 I tried the combination of hanger steak and butter lobster, which both yummy yummy yummy. For me, tempest RW food taste level is definitely higher than the most other restaurants. In addition, it has six choices for entree during RW (comparing to three choices for others). The crab soup is delicious as well. Key lime pie is good.  My husband tried cioppino (seafood combination), apple cherry crisp and clams.   You deserve to try it either restaurant week or normal time. By the way, smoke stack and oysters during happy hour is nice deal as well!!! Smoke stack is beautiful as oysters are juicy.

Went here on the first night of Restaurant week winter 2016, so I wasn't expecting everything to be perfect.  However, to have to wait about 15 minutes for our table (even though we had a reservation) and then another 15 min to be greeted by anyone, was a little ridiculous.  We were grateful to the server who took the initiative to help us after noticing we hadn't been.    Other than the service not being up to par (which is understandable during this busy time)  Almost everything else was perfect.  I had the steak and lobster which was a great value for the price.  The steak was delicious for a hangar steak.  The lobster however was a little under cooked and could have been cleaned a little better.  Either way, I enjoyed my night here and will definitely be back to see how the full menu and service compares to that of restaurant week.  Another Positive was I loved the decor.  It was very romantic and quaint, something different.

Wow!  I took my fiancee here to celebrate. We have lived in Madison for a long time but have only recently started getting adventurous with all the great food available. The interior of the restaurant has a very cool nautical theme. We arrived early, at the very start of service, so we had the dining room to ourselves for at least a little while. Our server was very attentive, knowledgeable and kind. We tried a lot of new things and he was always willing to help out.   We started with some cocktails--I had a very sweet whiskey drink and she had some kind of warm red wine. Neither one was probably something we would regularly order but very good nonetheless. We also had some oysters, obviously. It was our first time and the waiter did a good job of helping us pick them out. Very fresh and flavorful. We have been converted.   We then moved onto our appetizer--steamed mussels in some kind of butter and wine sauce. Again, very good. Perfectly cooked and seasoned. My fiancee, who had never had them, was converted once again.   For our entree, we both had the shrimp, scallops and grits. Very artfully presented, with pork belly and some kind of yummy sauce. I had a local Pale Ale with the dinner. We ended with a key lime pie.  All in all it was an unforgettable meal. Service was great and food was great. Definitely one of the best meals I've had in Madison.

In town for a visit, thought I'd try something new.    I heard good things about Tempest from friends, and I loved it.  The decor is really unique, and includes a beautifully aged wooden boat and a fun clamshell for seating.  I went for happy hour, and my waitress Lindsey was very helpful in showing me around the menu.  (I'm a bit of an oyster novice, myself.)  I started off with a great cocktail called a Tokyo Schooner made with sake and ginger.  Delicious.  My dining partner had an amazing bloody mary with cilantro vodka.  She says it's one of the best cocktails she's ever had.  We also had a couple oysters, which were fantastic.  Very fresh.  They really didn't need any sauce, but there was a house vinagrette with scallions that complemented them perfectly.  But my favorite was the Smoke Stack, a great little stack of smoked trout, whitefish salad, and vegetables that was superb.  The best part?  It was so inexpensive!  I'm looking forward to coming back when I'm in Madison again.
Excellent!! Loved the oysters service and location. We've taken customers here twice and they did real well!!  Suggest this one highly

Went to Tempest earlier this week, looking forward to sampling the Lobster Roll. Unfortunately we were very disappointed! The lobster was chewy and overdone, and it was on a hoagie bun w/lettuce, mayo, and pickles?? I have never had a Lobster Roll like this one. I know we are in the midwest, but try to make it somewhat authentic.... The tuna appetizer was well done, as were the matchstick french fries. I will give this this restaurant another try, but definitely not order the Lobster Roll.
